title: Ticket #7060: Easy way to do "condor_submit_dag" from Python
description:
Based on discussions at HTCondor week, it'd be useful if there was a "simple" way to submit DAGs to HTCondor, via the python bindings, based on an existing DAG file.

We should do this short-term while we are thinking through the official DAG API that includes constructing the DAG itself.
remarks:
2019-May-21 14:31:46 by coatsworth:
I already have a Python binding for DAGMan ready to go. The API for using it looks something like this: 

dag = htcondor.Dag()
dag.LoadFromFile("sleep.dag")
dag_args = {
	"maxidle" : 10,
	"maxpost": 5
}
submit = dag.Submit(dag_args)

schedd = htcondor.Schedd()
with schedd.transaction() as txn:
	cluster_id = submit.queue(txn, 1)
	print("Submit.queue returned cluster_id = " + str(cluster_id))

This effort stalled a few months ago and there were two main reasons for this:

  1. The binding fundamentally depends on a .dag file and always will. There was a lot of opposition to this.
  2. Josh was looking into an interface to programatically generate DAGs, and we were colliding on the API namespace.

The second problem is easily solved. The first one is not. Removing the dependency on the .dag file is a massive engineering effort that is not realistic. I think we need to accept this in order to move forward.

2019-May-21 14:46:04 by bbockelm:
Can we simplify this slightly? How about: 

with open("sleep.dag", "r") as fp:
    dag = htcondor.Dag(fp.read())

schedd = htcondor.Schedd()
with schedd.transaction() as txn:
	handle = dag.queue(maxidle = 10, maxpost = 5)
	print("Submit.queue returned cluster_id = {}".format(handle.cluster()))

2019-May-21 14:50:52 by karpel:
dag = htcondor.Dag.from_file(path_to_file) is much saner. Users should not have to read the file in themselves.

Having a single htcondor.Dag (htcondor.DAG?) object without needing another htcondor.Submit makes more sense to me.

The actual submission seems sensible, but I don't know enough about DAGs to say which arguments should be part of the htcondor.Dag object and which should be arguments to the queue command.

2019-May-21 14:56:57 by bbockelm:
  dag = htcondor.Dag.from_file(path_to_file) is much saner. Users should not have to read the file in themselves.

Sounds good to me. I went with the constructor-based approach for symmetry with Submit.

  Having a single htcondor.Dag (htcondor.DAG?) object without needing another htcondor.Submit makes more sense to me.

I like DAG. I think of Submit as meaning "submit file" object, not "submit to queue". Hence, since DAG is separate file format, I thought it made a lot of sense to have a separate object.

  The actual submission seems sensible, but I don't know enough about DAGs to say which arguments should be part of the htcondor.Dag object and which should be arguments to the queue command.

Given I want the DAG object to represent a DAG file, I think of queue as the instantiation of the DAG -- hence I put the arguments in the queue method.

2019-May-21 14:59:32 by coatsworth:
This is shorter but not simpler. Also there are some things that just won't work, ie. passing file pointers as function parameters won't work in Windows.

We should discuss the API offline. I also want to get some feedback from Collin and other users so we make these decisions based on what they need, not what we think is best.

2019-May-21 15:21:33 by karpel:
Related question, now that I'm actually reading the ticket: do the bindings themselves need an in-memory DAG representation if there's no way to use it except to write out actual files? Or do we just need a high-level tool (htcondor-jobs or whatever) that helps users make those files in a sensible way?

2019-May-22 07:43:27 by bbockelm:
Right - that's a good point. So, the syntax becomes: 

dag = htcondor.Dag(filename="sleep.dag")

schedd = htcondor.Schedd()
with schedd.transaction() as txn:
	handle = dag.queue(maxidle = 10, maxpost = 5)
	print("Submit.queue returned cluster_id = {}".format(handle.cluster()))

2019-Jun-01 15:54:35 by karpel:
Given that there's currently no plan to let you do anything but submit an existing DAG file, why not 

import htcondor

schedd = htcondor.Schedd()
with schedd.transaction() as txn:
	handle = htcondor.submit_dag(path_to_dagfile, maxidle = 10, maxpost = 5)
	print("cluster_id = {}".format(handle.cluster()))

Doubly-so given that even if we added an API for building DAG files, we would want to keep that in-memory representation quite separate from the submission process to emphasize that the file on disk is the source of truth for DAGMan.

2019-Aug-06 11:29:36 by coatsworth:
This ticket is a duplicate of #6275, and since I was referencing that ticket in my commits I'm going to make it the "official" ticket for the condor_submit_dag python binding. The work is also complete at this point so I'm marking this as resolved, version history and documentation will reference #6275.
